prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Pendency of MDL matters

para.paratext: The Panel has expressly stated that the fact a district has no pending dockets of multidistrict matters transferred by the Panel is a factor that favors transfer to that district.[1] Similarly, the fact a court is “not overtaxed” with MDL dockets has been noted by the Panel as supporting transfer to that district.[2] The Panel as also noted that the fact a district has a “relatively low number” of MDL dockets favors its selection as a transferee district.[3] This reflects the increasing tendency of the Panel to transfer cases broadly throughout the federal system. In one case, the Panel observed: “With the increasing number of MDLs, it becomes helpful to spread the burden of them among districts, where we can do so and still retain the benefits of convenience which Section 1407 requires.”[4]

This factor may be persuasive to the Panel, and a party seeking transfer to a particular district should pay attention to it. Indeed, this factor may “trump” the otherwise strong rule that the Panel will not generally transfer to a district where no actions are pending.[5] The Panel includes on its website a link to a table showing the distribution of pending multidistrict dockets. That table is included as Appendix D to this work and is available on the Panel's website.[6] This factor may also work to avoid an otherwise logical transferee court. In one case, the Panel specifically identified a judge as being well-suited to handle a docket, but transferred the docket to another district because that judge was already handling two MDL dockets.[7] Similarly, the Panel has noted the opportunity to transfer to a judge (not necessarily a district) with no pending MDL matters.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See, e.g., In re Fresh and Process Potatoes Antitrust Litigation, 744 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2010) (district has no pending MDL dockets); In re Simply Orange Orange Juice Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 867 F. Supp. 2d 1344 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (experienced judge not currently overseeing an MDL docket); In re Skelaxin (Metaxalone) Antitrust Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1350 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (district with only one other MDL docket); In re Carrier IQ, Inc., Consumer Privacy Litigation, 856 F. Supp. 2d 1332 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (judge has MDL experience but no current assignments); In re Electronic Books Antitrust Litigation, 846 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (judge with no assigned MDL dockets); In re Horizon Organic Milk Plus DHA OMEGA-3 Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 844 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2012) (district has fewer MDL dockets than other districts); In re Actos Products Liability Litigation, 840 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (no pending MDLs in district); In re Dial Complete Marketing Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Certainteed Fiber Cement Siding Litigation, 802 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (judge not currently presiding over MDL actions); In re Digitek Products Liability Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Total Body Formula Products Liability Litigation, 582 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2008); In re Pilgrim's Pride Fair Labor Standards Litigation, 489 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re American Family Mut. Ins. Co., 416 F. Supp. 2d 1346 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Teflon Products Liability Litigation, 416 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 381 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (transfer to district with no pending MDL dockets despite no actions pending there); In re Farmers Insurance Co., Inc., Insurance Premiums Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re National Century Financial Enterprises, Inc., 293 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Wireless Telephone Federal Cost Recovery Fees Litigation, 293 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Pressure Sensitive Labelstock Antitrust Litigation, 290 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2003).

In re Serzone Products Liability Litigation, 217 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2002); see also In re Baycol Products Liability Litigation, 180 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re Inter-Op Hip Prosthesis Products Liability Litigation, 149 F. Supp. 2d 931 (J.P.M.L. 2001).

In re Indianapolis Life Ins. Co. I.R.S. 412(I) Plans Life Ins. Marketing Litigation, 581 F. Supp. 2d 1364 (J.P.M.L. 2008). See also In re Trasylol Products Liability Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (relatively few MDL dockets pending).

In re Digitek Products Liability Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1376, 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (docket transferred to experienced MDL judge in district with no matters currently assigned). See also In re NuvaRing Products Liability Litigation, 572 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer to district with relatively low number of pending MDL dockets); In re Panacryl Sutures Products Liability Litigation, 572 F. Supp. 2d 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transferee forum “has been underutilized as a transferee district”); In re Puerto Rican Cabotage Antitrust Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2008).

See In re Fedex Ground Package System, Inc., Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 381 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2005). The role of pendency of at least one action in the transferee district is discussed in §§ 5:23 & 6:8, above.
In re Hawaiian and Guamanian Cabotage Antitrust Litigation, 571 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2008).
See, e.g., In re Wal-Mart ATM Fee Notice Litigation, 785 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011).
